chapter.htmlHeader: What is the NHS bowel screening programme in the UK?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Recommendations on population screening are made by the UK National Screening Committee (UK NSC) to ministers in the 4 UK countries.
    • In 2016 the UK NSC recommended that faecal immunochemical testing (FIT) should replace guaiac faecal occult blood testing (gFOBt) as the primary test for bowel cancer screening.
      • FIT replaced gFOBt in Scotland in 2017 — for more information, see the section on the NHS bowel cancer screening programme in Scotland.
      • FIT is being introduced as the primary screening test in England and Wales in 2019  — for more information, see the sections on the NHS bowel cancer screening programme in England and the NHS bowel cancer screening programme in Wales.
      • At the time of writing (May 2019) FIT has not yet been introduced to the screening programme in Northern Ireland and gFOBt remains the primary screening test — for more information, see the section on the NHS bowel cancer screening programme in Northern Ireland.
  • In addition to faecal occult blood screening, one-off flexible sigmoidoscopy (Bowelscope) screening was introduced to areas of England in 2013.

[UK NSC, 2016; PHE, 2018]

subChapters.fullItemName: People known to be at high risk of bowel cancer
Bowel cancer screening programme in England
subChapters.htmlHeader: What is the NHS Bowel cancer screening programme in England?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• In England screening for faecal blood is offered every two years to people aged 60-74 years who are registered with a General Practice.
    • From 2019 the guaiac faecal occult blood test (FOBt) will be replaced by the faecal immunochemical test (FIT) with an initial threshold of 120µg haemoglobin/g faeces.
    • A change in the age at which screening starts in England to 50 years of age is planned for the future.
    • People older than 75 years of age can request a screening kit every 2 years by ringing the freephone number 0800 707 6060.
  • In addition to faecal occult blood screening, one-off flexible sigmoidoscopy (Bowelscope) screening was introduced to areas of England in 2013.
    • People aged 55 years who are registered with a GP and living in areas where the test is available are automatically sent an invitation.
    • If polyps are identified these are biopsied and the rest of the bowel is examined by colonoscopy.
    • Depending on individual preference Bowelscope screening can be deferred to any time before the age of 60 — after this age the person will be eligible for 2 yearly faecal occult blood bowel cancer screening.

[UK NSC, 2016; Koo, 2017; PHE, 2018; Cancer Research UK, 2019e]

subChapters.fullItemName: Bowel cancer screening programme in Scotland
subChapters.htmlHeader: What is the NHS Bowel cancer screening programme in Scotland?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The NHS Bowel Cancer Screening Programme in Scotland:

  • Offers bowel screening with the faecal immunochemical test (FIT) every two years to people aged 50-74 years who are registered with a General Practice.
    • The FIT test was introduced in November 2017 and replaces the previous guaiac faecal occult blood test (gFOBt) — the initial threshold for FIT is 80 μgHb/g faeces (this may change in the future).
  • People older than the maximum automatic screening age can request a screening kit every 2 years by ringing 0800 0121 833 or by emailing the helpline at bowelscreening.tayside@nhs.net.

[UK NSC, 2016; Koo, 2017; NHS Health Scotland, 2017; Cancer Research UK, 2019c]

subChapters.fullItemName: Bowel cancer screening programme in Wales
subChapters.htmlHeader: What is the NHS bowel cancer screening programme in Wales?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The NHS Bowel Cancer Screening Programme in Wales:

  • Offers screening for faecal blood every two years to people aged 60-74 years who are registered with a General Practice.
    • A change in the age at which screening starts in Wales to 50 years of age is planned by 2023.
    • Requests for screening outside the screening age group are not currently accepted.
  • From January 2019 the faecal immunochemical test (FIT) will replace the previously used guaiac faecal occult blood test (gFOBt) (full roll out is expected in June 2019).
    • The sensitivity level for the FIT test has initially been set at 150 micrograms of haemoglobin per gram of faeces with the aim of reducing to 80 micrograms of haemoglobin per gram of faeces by 2023.
  • The helpline number for the Bowel Cancer Screening Programme in Wales is 0800 294 3370.

[Koo, 2017; Bowel Screening Wales, 2019b]  [Cancer Research UK, 2019f]

subChapters.fullItemName: Bowel cancer screening programme in Northern Ireland
subChapters.htmlHeader: What is the NHS bowel cancer screening programme in Northern Ireland?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The NHS Bowel Cancer Screening Programme in Northern Ireland:

  • Offers bowel screening with the guaiac faecal occult blood test (gFOBt) to people aged 60–74 years who are registered with a GP.
  • Currently does not accept requests for screening outside this age group.
  • The Freephone helpline for the bowel cancer screening programme in Northern Ireland is 0800 015 2514.

[Koo, 2017; Cancer Research UK, 2019b]
